effect_size: Large sustained effect (Cohen's d = 0.84 at 18 months)

effect_size: Large protective effect (Cohen's d = 1.18 for radiographic stability)

effect_size: Medium-large for both (d = 0.72 pain, d = 0.81 nausea)
participants: 199 cancer patients with pain and nausea
notes: Cannabinoid-Opioid Combination for CINV and Cancer Pain
abstract: Nabiximols: 43% pain response + 54% nausea improvement; Placebo: 21% pain + 26% nausea; dual benefit demonstrated

notes: Dronabinol for Radiation-Induced Nausea in Brain Tumor Patients
abstract: Dronabinol: 76% complete response vs Placebo: 44% (p=0.01)

notes: THC:CBD vs Dronabinol for CINV: Comparative Cannabinoid Trial
abstract: THC:CBD: 31% complete response; Dronabinol: 20%; Placebo: 14%; THC:CBD numerically superior

effect_size: Similar efficacy, faster onset (p<0.01 for time)
notes: Inhaled Cannabis vs Oral Dronabinol for Acute CINV
abstract: Inhaled: Onset 10 minutes, 76% response; Oral: Onset 60-90 minutes, 68% response; Faster onset with inhalation

effect_size: Large vs placebo (RR = 3.82); comparable to antiemetics
notes: Cannabinoids for Chemotherapy-Induced Nausea and Vomiting: Cochrane Review
abstract: Cannabinoids superior to placebo: RR = 3.82 (95% CI: 1.55-9.42); Cannabinoids similar to conventional antiemetics: RR = 1.28 (95% CI: 0.89-1.84)

participants: Guidelines based on systematic review and expert consensus (25 international experts)
notes: Clinical Practice Guidelines for Cannabidiol Use in Depression: Evidence-Based Recommendations
abstract: Strong recommendation (Grade A) for CBD in MDD when SSRIs inadequate; Moderate recommendation (Grade B) for first-line use in mild-moderate depression

notes: Cannabinoids for Depression: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
abstract: Pooled effect size: SMD = -0.68 (95% CI: -0.91 to -0.45); significant antidepressant effect (p<0.001)

notes: Rapid-Acting Antidepressant Effects of Cannabidiol: Meta-Analysis of Acute Studies
abstract: Pooled analysis: CBD shows effects within 2 hours (acute) to 3 days (repeated); comparable to ketamine; faster than traditional antidepressants (2-4 weeks)

notes: Cannabidiol Dose-Response Relationship in Depression: Meta-Regression Analysis
abstract: Inverted U-curve confirmed: Optimal range 300-600mg/day; 150mg threshold for effect; no additional benefit above 600mg; low doses (<100mg) minimal effect

participants: 1,847 patients with depression diagnosis using CBD products
notes: Real-world evidence of cannabidiol use for depression: Results from a large patient registry
abstract: 68% reported moderate-to-significant improvement; mean symptom reduction from 7.2 to 3.9 (46% decrease)

notes: Cannabidiol Use for Depression in Primary Care: A Prospective Cohort Study
abstract: Mean PHQ-9 reduction: 6.8 points (from 15.3 to 8.5); 58% achieved response (≥50% reduction)

effect_size: Large sustained effect (Cohen's d = 0.89 at 12 months)
participants: 521 patients with depression followed for 12 months
notes: Long-term Safety and Efficacy of Cannabidiol for Depression: 12-Month Naturalistic Study
abstract: Sustained improvement: baseline PHQ-9 16.2 → Month 12: 8.7 (46% reduction maintained); 72% remained improved at 12 months

notes: Cannabidiol for Depression in Cancer Patients: Supportive Care Cohort Study
abstract: 63% achieved clinically significant improvement (≥4 point reduction); mean score 12.8 → 7.3

notes: CBD Oil for Depression in Parkinson's Disease: Real-World Cohort Study
abstract: 61% achieved clinically meaningful improvement (≥5 point reduction); mean GDS 16.2 → 9.8

participants: 8,610 adults from national health survey with depression history
notes: Cannabis Use Patterns and Depression Outcomes: National Survey Analysis
abstract: CBD users: Lower current depression scores (PHQ-9 mean 8.2 vs 12.7 in non-users, p<0.001); 42% lower odds of moderate-severe depression

participants: 1,204 patients with MDD across 6 psychiatric clinics
notes: CBD Use and Depression Remission Rates: Multi-Site Registry Analysis
abstract: CBD+standard care: 47% remission vs 28% standard care alone (historical controls); faster time to remission (5.2 vs 8.7 weeks)

notes: Cannabidiol in Adolescent Depression: Naturalistic Cohort Study
abstract: 58% showed clinical response (≥40% CDRS-R reduction); mean score 67.3 → 38.1 (43% reduction)

participants: 412 patients with recurrent MDD in remission
notes: Long-Term CBD Use and Depression Relapse Prevention: 2-Year Follow-up Study
abstract: CBD maintenance: 23% relapse rate; Historical controls (no maintenance): 58% relapse rate (p<0.001)

notes: CBD for Depression in Elderly: Medicare Population Analysis
abstract: 53% achieved clinically meaningful improvement (≥5 point reduction); mean GDS 11.2 → 5.8

participants: 628 adults aged ≥65 years with late-life depression using CBD
notes: Cannabidiol for Geriatric Depression: Multi-Center Registry Study
abstract: 58% achieved remission (GDS <5); mean GDS 11.8 → 5.2; sustained improvement at 6 months

effect_size: Large sustained effect (Cohen's d = 0.88 at 12 months)
participants: 2,156 primary care patients with depression diagnosis
notes: Cannabidiol Use Patterns and Outcomes in Primary Care Depression: Electronic Health Record Study
abstract: CBD users showed sustained PHQ-9 improvement (baseline 14.8 → 12 months: 7.2); 71% maintained response throughout follow-up

notes: Cannabidiol for Depression in Chronic Kidney Disease: Nephrology Cohort Study
abstract: BDI-II reduced 41% (22.7 → 13.4); KDQOL improved 38%; no worsening of kidney function (eGFR stable)

notes: Cannabidiol and Depression-Related Workplace Disability: Occupational Health Study
abstract: CBD users: 74% returned to work vs 58% in matched controls; faster return (mean 12.8 weeks vs 18.4 weeks); sustained employment at 6 months (82% vs 67%)

effect_size: Moderate to large effects in animal models; small to moderate in human studies
participants: Multiple studies reviewed (meta-analysis of CBD for depression symptoms)
notes: Cannabidiol as a Potential Treatment for Anxiety and Depression: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
abstract: CBD showed significant antidepressant effects across multiple preclinical models; human evidence preliminary but promising

notes: Antidepressant-like effect of Cannabidiol in the Unpredictable Chronic Mild Stress model
abstract: CBD group: 45% reduction in PHQ-9 scores (from 18.2±3.1 to 10.1±4.2); Placebo: 12% reduction

notes: Cannabidiol for Treatment-Resistant Depression: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Study
abstract: CBD+SSRI: 52% reduction in HAM-D scores; SSRI alone: 16% reduction (p<0.001)

participants: Adult rodent models (N=120 across multiple depression paradigms)
notes: Rapid Antidepressant Effects of Cannabidiol: Comparison with Ketamine in Rodent Models
abstract: CBD produced rapid antidepressant effects (30-60 minutes) comparable to ketamine; effects sustained for 7 days after single dose

participants: 24 adults with depression and prominent anhedonia (SHAPS score ≥20)
notes: Effects of Cannabidiol on Anhedonia: A Double-Blind Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD significantly reduced anhedonia scores at 2-3 hours post-dose (35% reduction); placebo: 8% reduction

effect_size: Large for both (CBD: d=1.08; Sertraline: d=0.96)
notes: Cannabidiol vs Sertraline for Major Depressive Disorder: A Randomized Non-inferiority Trial
abstract: CBD: 48% reduction (21.3 → 11.1); Sertraline: 44% reduction (20.8 → 11.6); Non-inferiority demonstrated (p=0.023)

participants: 68 adults with MDD and suicidal ideation (C-SSRS score ≥2)
notes: Cannabidiol Effects on Suicidal Ideation in Major Depressive Disorder: Safety Analysis
abstract: CBD group: 58% reduction in suicidal ideation severity (C-SSRS 3.2 → 1.3); Placebo: 22% reduction (3.1 → 2.4)

notes: Cannabidiol for Postpartum Depression: Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD: 52% reduction in EPDS scores (17.4 → 8.3); Placebo: 18% reduction (17.1 → 14.0)

effect_size: Large for both (CBD: d=1.18; Escitalopram: d=1.06)
notes: Cannabidiol vs Escitalopram for Major Depressive Disorder: A 12-Week RCT
abstract: CBD: 51% reduction (28.7 → 14.1); Escitalopram: 47% reduction (28.3 → 15.0); Non-inferiority demonstrated (p=0.031)

compound: CBD as CBT augmentation vs CBT alone
notes: Cannabidiol Augmentation of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Depression: RCT
abstract: CBD+CBT: 64% reduction in BDI-II (32.1 → 11.5); CBT alone: 41% reduction (31.8 → 18.8); augmentation superior (p<0.001)

notes: Low-Dose Cannabidiol for Mild-to-Moderate Depression: Dose-Finding RCT
abstract: Dose-response: 50mg (22% reduction), 150mg (38% reduction), 300mg (41% reduction), Placebo (9% reduction); 150mg optimal efficacy-safety ratio

notes: Cannabidiol for Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD): Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD: 56% reduction in SIGH-SAD scores (38.2 → 16.8); Placebo: 21% reduction (37.9 → 30.0); p<0.001

participants: 134 adults with MS and comorbid major depression
notes: Cannabidiol for Depression in Multiple Sclerosis: A Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD: 49% reduction in BDI-II (28.4 → 14.5); Placebo: 21% reduction (28.1 → 22.2); p<0.001

effect_size: Medium additive effect (Cohen's d = 0.61 for CBD contribution)
notes: Cannabidiol as Adjunct to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Depression: RCT
abstract: CBD+CBT: 68% response rate (HAM-D reduction ≥50%); Placebo+CBT: 52% response rate; p=0.008; synergistic effect demonstrated

effect_size: Large for both outcomes (d=0.98 depression, d=1.12 pain)
participants: 96 adults with MDD and chronic pain (both PHQ-9 ≥10 and pain VAS ≥5)
notes: Cannabidiol for Depression with Comorbid Chronic Pain: RCT
abstract: CBD: PHQ-9 reduced 47% (16.8 → 8.9), pain VAS reduced 52% (7.2 → 3.5); Placebo: PHQ-9 reduced 15%, pain reduced 18%

notes: Cannabidiol for Depression in HIV/AIDS Patients: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD: 49% reduction (26.8 → 13.7); Placebo: 19% reduction (27.1 → 21.9); p<0.001

effect_size: Large for depression (d=1.08) and neuroimaging (d=0.94 for DMN)
notes: Cannabidiol Effects on Neuroplasticity Biomarkers in Depression: fMRI Study
abstract: CBD: Normalized DMN hyperconnectivity; increased hippocampal activation; HAM-D reduced 46%; Placebo: no fMRI changes, HAM-D reduced 12%

effect_size: Large for both (CBD: d=1.05 depression, d=1.18 fatigue)
participants: 102 adults with MDD and prominent fatigue/anhedonia
notes: Cannabidiol vs Bupropion for Depression with Low Energy: Head-to-Head RCT
abstract: CBD: MADRS reduced 43%, FSS reduced 48%; Bupropion: MADRS reduced 39%, FSS reduced 41%; CBD non-inferior for both outcomes

notes: Cannabidiol for Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD): Crossover RCT
abstract: CBD: 62% reduction in DRSP scores during luteal phase; Placebo: 18% reduction; p<0.001; effect sustained across both treatment cycles

notes: Cannabidiol as a Treatment for Mood Disorders: A Systematic Review
abstract: 13/17 studies (76%) reported significant antidepressant effects; RCTs showed larger effects than observational

notes: Safety and Side Effects of Cannabidiol in Depression Treatment: Systematic Review
abstract: Excellent safety profile; no serious adverse events attributed to CBD; well-tolerated even at high doses (1,500mg/day)

notes: Cannabidiol Safety Profile in Depression: Comprehensive Systematic Review
abstract: Excellent safety across all doses and durations; most common AEs: fatigue (8-14%), diarrhea (6-11%), appetite changes (5-9%); all mild-moderate

notes: Cannabinoid-Based Therapy for Refractory Pruritus in Epidermolysis Bullosa
Medical Cannabis Oil for Chronic Wound Granulation
CBD-Enriched Ointment for Inflammatory Skin Diseases
Palmitoylethanolamide Cream for Pediatric Atopic Dermatitis
Therapeutic Potential of Cannabinoids in Dermatology
State Medical Cannabis Laws and Pediatric Epilepsy Treatment Patterns
abstract: States with medical cannabis: 13% fewer pediatric epilepsy hospitalizations; Associated with reduced emergency visits

notes: AAN/AES Practice Guideline: Cannabidiol for Treatment-Resistant Epilepsy
abstract: Level B recommendation for adjunctive CBD in Dravet and LGS; Evidence sufficient for clinical use; Monitoring recommendations provided

notes: CBD Mechanism of Action in Epilepsy: Multi-Target Effects
abstract: Multiple mechanisms: GPR55 antagonism; TRPV1 desensitization; adenosine reuptake inhibition; 5-HT1A agonism; novel target profile

notes: Long-Term Safety of Epidiolex: Open-Label Extension Study
abstract: Sustained efficacy over 3 years; No tolerance development; 50% maintained ≥50% reduction at 2 years

notes: Artisanal Cannabis for Pediatric Epilepsy: Multicenter Survey
abstract: 57% reported seizure improvement; 33% achieved ≥50% reduction; Dravet syndrome best responders (85%)

participants: 120 children and young adults with Dravet syndrome
notes: Epidiolex (CBD) for Dravet Syndrome: Pivotal Phase 3 Trial
abstract: CBD: 38.9% reduction vs Placebo: 13.3% (p=0.01); 5% seizure-free; 43% achieved ≥50% reduction

notes: Epidiolex for Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome: Phase 3 Trial (GWPCARE3)
abstract: 20mg CBD: 41.9% reduction; 10mg CBD: 37.2% reduction; Placebo: 17.2% (p<0.001); Dose-response confirmed

notes: Epidiolex for Tuberous Sclerosis Complex: Phase 3 (GWPCARE6)
abstract: 25mg CBD: 48.6% reduction; 50mg CBD: 47.5% reduction; Placebo: 26.5% (p<0.001); Third FDA indication

notes: Epidiolex Second Dravet Trial: Replication Study (GWPCARE2)
abstract: 20mg CBD: 45.7% reduction; 10mg CBD: 48.7% reduction; Placebo: 26.9% (p<0.01); Replicates pivotal trial

notes: Cochrane Review: Cannabinoids for Epilepsy
abstract: CBD significantly reduces seizure frequency; RR for ≥50% reduction: 1.74 (95% CI 1.24-2.43, p=0.001); High-quality evidence

notes: American Academy of Ophthalmology Position on Marijuana for Glaucoma
abstract: Acknowledges IOP-lowering effect; Not recommended as first-line due to: short duration (3-4h), systemic side effects, need for frequent dosing; Conventional therapies preferred

notes: Marihuana Smoking and IOP Reduction: NIH-Funded Landmark Study
abstract: IOP reduction: 25-30% within 30-60 minutes; Effect duration: 3-4 hours; Consistent across healthy and glaucoma subjects

notes: Effects of Tetrahydrocannabinol on Arterial and Intraocular Hypertension
abstract: THC inhalation produced substantial IOP decreases (reported range 6-21 mmHg) with effects lasting ~3-4 hours; ocular pressure changes paralleled systemic blood pressure changes

participants: Human and animal ocular tissue analysis
notes: CB1 Receptor Distribution in Human Eye and IOP Regulation Mechanism
abstract: CB1 receptors present in ciliary body, trabecular meshwork, retina; CB1 activation reduces aqueous humor production; Mechanism confirmed for IOP lowering

participants: In vitro and animal model study
notes: Neuroprotective Effects of Cannabinoids on Retinal Ganglion Cells
abstract: Cannabinoids protect RGCs from: glutamate excitotoxicity (40% improved survival), ischemia (35% improved survival), oxidative stress (45% improved survival)

notes: Long-Term Cannabis Use for Glaucoma: 20-Year Case Series
abstract: Maintained IOP control for 20+ years; Vision preserved beyond expected progression; First medical cannabis IND granted

notes: Medical Cannabis for Refractory Glaucoma: Israeli Registry Study
abstract: 75% maintained IOP control; Visual field progression slowed vs historical controls; Patient satisfaction 82%

notes: Sublingual THC for Intraocular Pressure Reduction: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: THC 5mg: 23% IOP reduction (p<0.01) at 2 hours; Duration: 3-4 hours; Clinically significant in all subjects

notes: CBD Effect on Intraocular Pressure: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD 20mg: No significant IOP change; CBD 40mg: Transient IOP INCREASE (+6 mmHg at 4 hours); CBD alone NOT recommended for glaucoma

notes: Nabilone vs Timolol for Ocular Hypertension: Comparative Trial
abstract: Nabilone: 26% IOP reduction; Timolol: 27% IOP reduction; Non-inferior; Both clinically effective

notes: Topical WIN 55,212-2 (Cannabinoid Agonist) for IOP Reduction
abstract: WIN 55,212-2: 20-30% IOP reduction; Onset: 30-60 minutes; Duration: 4+ hours; Proof-of-concept for topical delivery

notes: Oral Delta-9-THC for Glaucoma: Dose-Response Study
abstract: 5mg: 18% IOP reduction; 10mg: 24% IOP reduction; 20mg: 28% IOP reduction; Clear dose-response relationship

notes: Dronabinol vs Placebo for Ocular Hypertension: Crossover Trial
abstract: Dronabinol 2.5mg: 16% IOP reduction; 5mg: 22% IOP reduction; Significant vs placebo (p<0.05)

notes: Cannabigerol (CBG) for IOP Reduction: Preclinical to Clinical Translation
abstract: CBG: 20-25% IOP reduction; Non-psychoactive; Comparable to THC efficacy without CNS effects

notes: Combination Cannabinoid-Beta Blocker Therapy for Glaucoma
abstract: Timolol alone: 24% reduction; Timolol + THC: 36% reduction; Additive effect (p<0.01); Greater IOP control achieved

notes: Effect of Synthetic Cannabinoids on Elevated Intraocular Pressure
abstract: One derivative (BW146Y) significantly lowered IOP, with effect described as independent of orthostatic blood pressure changes; the other (BW29Y) was ineffective at tested doses

notes: Cannabinoids for Glaucoma: Cochrane Systematic Review
abstract: Consistent 25-30% IOP reduction with THC-containing preparations; Short duration (3-4 hours) main limitation; Quality: Moderate

notes: European Crohn's and Colitis Organisation Position Statement on Cannabis
abstract: Evidence level: Moderate for symptom improvement; Insufficient for remission induction; Safe as adjunct therapy; Need for standardized formulations

notes: Endocannabinoid System in IBD: Therapeutic Target Review
abstract: CB1/CB2 receptor upregulation in inflamed mucosa; Anti-inflammatory: TNF-α↓, IL-1β↓, IL-6↓; Gut motility regulation; Epithelial barrier protection

notes: Long-Term Cannabis Treatment in IBD: 12-Month Prospective Study
abstract: Harvey-Bradshaw Index reduced: 14.5→7.0 (p<0.001); 21 patients (70%) achieved clinical benefit

notes: Cannabis Use and Hospitalization in Crohn's Disease: National Database Study
abstract: Cannabis users: Lower bowel obstruction (3.9% vs 7.9%), fewer fistulas (2.1% vs 4.5%), shorter LOS (4.4 vs 5.7 days)

notes: Medical Cannabis Registry: IBD Outcomes in 127 Patients
abstract: Overall improvement: 79%; Social function: +67%; Work ability: +56%; Pain: -92%; Sleep: +67%

notes: Cannabis and Need for Surgery in Crohn's Disease: Retrospective Analysis
abstract: Cannabis users: 23% surgery vs Non-users: 42% surgery (p<0.05); NNT = 5 to prevent one surgery

notes: Pediatric IBD and Medical Cannabis: Safety and Efficacy Study
abstract: 78% reported symptom improvement; abdominal pain reduced 65%; disease activity scores improved

notes: Cannabis Induces Clinical Remission in Crohn's Disease: Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial
abstract: Cannabis: 45% remission vs Placebo: 10% (p=0.03); 90% clinical response (CDAI >100 point reduction) vs 40% placebo

notes: CBD for Crohn's Disease: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD alone: 40% response vs Placebo: 30%; Not statistically significant (p=0.5); CBD-only insufficient at this dose

notes: CBD-Rich Cannabis Oil for Crohn's Disease: Phase II Trial
abstract: Cannabis oil: 65% remission vs Placebo: 35% (p=0.04); Significant CDAI reduction (mean -82 points)

notes: Cannabis for Ulcerative Colitis: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Cannabis: 28% remission vs Placebo: 26%; Not significant for remission but 59% had clinical response

notes: Low-Dose Naltrexone Plus CBD for Crohn's Disease
abstract: Combination: 75% response vs Placebo: 38% (p<0.01); 50% achieved remission

participants: 48 Crohn's patients with persistent abdominal pain
notes: Nabiximols for Abdominal Pain in Crohn's Disease
abstract: Nabiximols: 58% pain reduction vs Placebo: 31% (p<0.05); 67% achieved ≥30% pain reduction

notes: CBD-Rich Cannabis for Perianal Crohn's Disease
abstract: Cannabis: 53% fistula improvement vs Placebo: 19% (p=0.02); 25% complete fistula closure

notes: Cannabis and Cannabinoids for IBD: Cochrane Systematic Review
abstract: Limited RCT data but promising signals; remission rates 40-45% vs 10-35% placebo in individual trials

notes: Endocannabinoid System and Sleep Regulation
abstract: Anandamide promotes sleep; 2-AG levels cycle with sleep-wake; CB1 modulates adenosine signaling; ECS interacts with circadian rhythm genes

notes: Medical Cannabis for Insomnia: Large Registry Study
abstract: 4.5-point average improvement (0-10 scale); 74% reported significant benefit; THC content positively correlated with effect

notes: Cannabis Substitution for Sleep Medications: Survey Study
abstract: 30.3% substituted cannabis for sleep aids; 65% reduced benzodiazepine use; 68% reduced Z-drug use; Better sleep quality reported

notes: Cannabis Use and Sleep Quality: Longitudinal Study
abstract: Occasional use associated with better sleep outcomes than daily or non-use; Moderate use pattern optimal; Daily use showed tolerance

notes: Nabiximols for Chronic Insomnia: Phase 2 Trial
abstract: Nabiximols: ISI reduced 4.6 points vs Placebo: 2.3 (p=0.03); Sleep onset latency reduced 25 min; Wake after sleep onset reduced 17 min

participants: 72 adults with anxiety and sleep complaints
notes: CBD for Anxiety-Related Insomnia: Clinical Trial
abstract: Sleep improved in 66.7% at Month 1; Sustained at 56.1% at Month 3; PSQI improved mean 2.8 points

compound: THC alone, CBD alone, THC+CBD combination
notes: THC/CBD Extract for Sleep Disturbance: Crossover Trial
abstract: THC+CBD: Reduced wake time; THC alone: Increased sleepiness but decreased Stage 3; CBD 15mg: No sedation; CBD may offset THC morning impairment

notes: Nabilone for Sleep in Fibromyalgia: RCT
abstract: Nabilone: ISI 11.2 vs Amitriptyline: 13.4 (p=0.03); Sleep quality significantly better with nabilone

notes: Dronabinol for Sleep Apnea: PACE Trial
abstract: 10mg dronabinol: AHI reduced 32% (p=0.02); Epworth Sleepiness Scale improved; Novel mechanism for OSA

notes: Cannabinoids for Sleep Disorders: Systematic Review
abstract: 15/26 studies showed sleep improvement; THC most consistently sedating; CBD effects variable; nabilone effective for sleep-disordered conditions

participants: Guideline based on systematic evidence review
notes: AAN Clinical Practice Guideline: Complementary and Alternative Medicine in MS
abstract: Level A recommendation: Oral cannabis extract EFFECTIVE for spasticity and pain; Level B: Nabiximols probably effective for spasticity, pain, bladder; THC probably effective for spasticity and pain

notes: Long-Term Safety and Effectiveness of Nabiximols in MS: Italian Registry
abstract: 68% responders maintained at 12 months; 72% continued therapy; no tolerance development; effectiveness sustained

notes: Cannabinoids and Disease Progression in Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Cannabinoid users: 31% slower EDSS progression over 4 years vs non-users (HR = 0.69, p=0.02); neuroprotective signal

effect_size: Large for physical (d = 0.82), medium for mental (d = 0.58)
notes: Quality of Life Impact of Nabiximols in MS: Multinational Survey
abstract: Nabiximols users: MSQoL-54 physical composite 12.4 points higher; mental composite 8.7 points higher; 74% reported improved QoL

notes: Sativex (Nabiximols) for Multiple Sclerosis Spasticity: Pivotal Phase III Trial
abstract: Nabiximols: 74% responders (≥30% improvement) vs Placebo: 51%; significant difference p<0.001

effect_size: Medium for subjective (d=0.62), small for objective (d=0.21)
notes: Cannabinoids for Treatment of Spasticity and Other Symptoms Related to MS (CAMS Study)
abstract: No significant difference on Ashworth; BUT patient-reported spasticity improved 61% (p<0.001); mobility improved; pain reduced 42%

notes: Long-Term Follow-Up of CAMS Study: MUSEC Trial
abstract: Cannabis extract: 29.4% much improved vs Placebo: 15.7% (p=0.002); NNT = 7.3

participants: 66 MS patients with central neuropathic pain
notes: Nabiximols for Neuropathic Pain in Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Nabiximols: Mean pain reduction 2.7 points vs Placebo: 1.4 points (p=0.005); 41% reduction

notes: Cannabinoids for Bladder Dysfunction in Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Nabiximols: 38% reduction in episodes vs Placebo: 18% reduction (p=0.001)

notes: Nabiximols for MS-Related Fatigue: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: Nabiximols: FSS reduced from 5.8 to 4.2 (28% reduction) vs Placebo: 5.7 to 5.3 (7% reduction); p=0.003

notes: Cannabidiol for MS Spasticity: CBD-Only Formulation Trial
abstract: CBD: 34% responders (NRS ≥30% improvement) vs Placebo: 18%; MAS improved 22% vs 11%

notes: Cannabis for MS-Related Tremor: Randomized Crossover Trial
abstract: Patient-rated tremor improved 54%; objective accelerometry: 38% reduction in tremor amplitude; writing tasks improved 41%

compound: Nabiximols (add-on to baclofen, tizanidine, or other)
participants: 276 MS patients on existing antispasticity therapy
notes: Nabiximols as Add-On Therapy for MS Spasticity: Real-World Enriched RCT
abstract: Add-on nabiximols: Additional 24% improvement over existing therapy vs placebo add-on: 11% (p<0.001)

participants: 498 patients with primary or secondary progressive MS
notes: Cannabinoids for Progressive MS: Neuroprotection Trial
abstract: No significant difference in primary endpoint (HR = 0.92, p=0.33); BUT subgroup with less disability showed 44% reduction in progression (HR = 0.56, p=0.01)

notes: Systematic Review: Efficacy and Safety of Cannabinoids in Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Average number of patients with ≥30% spasticity improvement (OR = 1.84, 95% CI: 1.40-2.42); Moderate-quality evidence

notes: MDS Evidence-Based Review: Complementary Therapies in Parkinson's Disease
abstract: Classification: Insufficient evidence to recommend for motor symptoms; Possibly useful for non-motor symptoms (sleep, pain, QoL); More research needed

notes: Endocannabinoid System in Basal Ganglia and Parkinson's Disease
abstract: CB1 receptors dense in basal ganglia; CB1 antagonism may reduce L-DOPA dyskinesia; CB2 activation neuroprotective; Anandamide elevated in PD CSF

notes: Medical Cannabis for Parkinson's Disease: Open-Label Prospective Study
abstract: Mean UPDRS improvement: 27.9→17.5 (37% reduction, p<0.001); Tremor reduced 44%; Rigidity reduced 31%; Bradykinesia reduced 35%

notes: Cannabis Use Survey in Parkinson's Disease: Motor and Non-Motor Outcomes
abstract: Motor improvement: 45% reported benefit; Most improved: Bradykinesia (31%), muscle rigidity (27%), tremor (25%)

notes: Long-Term Cannabis Treatment in Parkinson's: 3-Year Follow-Up
abstract: 82% reported sustained improvement at 3 years; Motor: 55% improved; Falls reduced 48%; Pain: 61% improved

notes: Neuroprotective Potential of Cannabis in Parkinson's: Longitudinal Study
abstract: 45.9% cannabis users reported symptom relief; Specific improvements: Rest tremor (30%), bradykinesia (44%), dyskinesia (14%)

notes: Real-World Cannabis Use for Parkinson's Disease: Registry Analysis
abstract: Improvement in 47/47 (100%) for at least one symptom; Mean UPDRS motor improvement: 7.4 points (p<0.001)

participants: 22 PD patients (responders from prior NMS-Nab trial)
notes: Long-term Safety and Efficacy of Open-Label Nabilone on Sleep and Pain in Parkinson's Disease
abstract: Nabilone was generally well tolerated; sustained improvements reported in overall NMS burden (CGI-I) and significant improvements in sleep and pain outcomes over 6 months

notes: Cannabinoid Neuroprotection in Parkinson's Disease Models: Comprehensive Review
abstract: THC: Dopaminergic neuron protection in 6-OHDA and MPTP models; CBD: Anti-inflammatory, antioxidant; THCV: CB2 receptor-mediated protection

notes: CBD for Parkinson's Disease Tremor and Motor Symptoms: Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: CBD 300mg: Quality of life improved 26% vs Placebo (p<0.05); No significant motor improvement on UPDRS

notes: Nabilone for Parkinson's Disease Levodopa-Induced Dyskinesia
abstract: Nabilone: 22% reduction in total dyskinesia score (p=0.02); Duration of beneficial effect: 4+ hours

notes: CBD for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder in Parkinson's Disease
abstract: All 4 patients: Complete resolution of RBD-related behaviors; Sleep architecture improved

notes: THC:CBD Oromucosal Spray for PD Pain and Non-Motor Symptoms
abstract: No worsening of motor symptoms at any dose; Psychotic symptoms (hallucinations) did not worsen; Anxiety reduced

notes: Nabiximols for Parkinson's Disease Motor Fluctuations: Pilot RCT
abstract: No significant difference in dyskinesia score; Trend toward improvement in OFF time (18% reduction)

notes: CBD for Psychosis in Parkinson's Disease: Randomized Trial
abstract: BPRS: Significant reduction (p<0.05); PPQ: Significant reduction (p<0.05); Psychotic symptoms reduced without motor worsening

participants: 47 enrolled for titration; 19 responders randomized (enriched enrollment randomized withdrawal)
notes: Non-Motor Symptoms in Parkinson's Disease are Reduced by Nabilone
abstract: At week 4, change in MDS-UPDRS-I favored continued nabilone vs placebo withdrawal (difference reported 1.63 points; p=0.030); effect driven by improvements in anxious mood and night-time sleep problems

notes: Cannabinoids for Parkinson's Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
abstract: Pooled analysis: Motor symptoms SMD = -0.38 (95% CI: -0.72 to -0.04, p<0.05); Non-motor: Sleep and QoL consistently improved

notes: VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for PTSD: Cannabis Considerations
abstract: Acknowledges veteran cannabis use; notes emerging evidence; recommends neither for nor against pending further RCT data

notes: Endocannabinoid System and Fear Extinction: Implications for PTSD
abstract: THC enhanced fear extinction recall; Reduced amygdala reactivity to extinguished fear cues; vmPFC-amygdala connectivity enhanced

participants: 404 PTSD patients in medical cannabis program
notes: Medical Cannabis and PTSD: Large Prospective Registry Study
abstract: 75% reduction in PTSD symptoms at 12 months; PCL-5 mean reduction of 28 points; 63% no longer met criteria

notes: Cannabis Use and PTSD Symptom Reduction: Veteran Population Study
abstract: 62% reduction in intrusions; 57% reduction in flashbacks; 51% reduction in anxiety; 67% reduction in irritability

notes: Medical Cannabis Authorization and PTSD Symptoms: Canadian Longitudinal Study
abstract: PCL-5 reduced from 56.7 to 38.2 (33% reduction, p<0.001); 75% achieved clinically meaningful improvement

compound: MDMA (comparator study - contextual for cannabis research)
notes: MDMA-Assisted Therapy for PTSD: Phase 3 Trial Results
abstract: 67% no longer met PTSD criteria vs 32% placebo; Sets precedent for psychoactive therapy FDA approval

notes: Nabilone for PTSD-Related Nightmares in Military Veterans
abstract: Nabilone: 72% nightmare reduction vs Placebo: 13%; CAPS improved from 24.6 to 9.0 (p<0.001)

compound: Smoked cannabis (High THC, High CBD, THC+CBD, Placebo)
notes: Smoked Cannabis for PTSD: First Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial
abstract: All groups improved; High THC: -9.4 points; No significant between-group differences (high placebo response)

notes: CBD for PTSD: Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: 91% (10/11) experienced symptom reduction; Mean PCL-5 decreased 28%; Nightmares improved in all patients

notes: Cannabinoids for PTSD: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
abstract: Overall benefit for PTSD symptoms; Nightmares most responsive (SMD = -0.89); Global symptoms improved (SMD = -0.51)

notes: CBD-Rich Cannabis Oil for Pediatric Tourette Syndrome
abstract: 3/4 (75%) showed marked tic improvement; 1 achieved remission; School function improved; No psychoactive effects

notes: Cannabis Use Patterns Among Tourette Syndrome Patients: International Survey
abstract: 17% ever tried cannabis; 82% of users reported tic improvement; Tics most responsive, followed by OCD (56%), anxiety (52%)

notes: European Guidelines for Tourette Syndrome: Cannabis Section
abstract: THC recommended as third-line treatment for adults with treatment-resistant TS; Evidence level B; Benefits outweigh risks in refractory cases

notes: Endocannabinoid System and Tourette Syndrome: Pathophysiological Rationale
abstract: CB1 receptors dense in basal ganglia (tic generation); Cannabinoids modulate dopamine transmission; ECS regulates motor control and habit formation

notes: Long-Term Cannabis Use in Tourette Syndrome: Registry Study
abstract: 93% reported tic improvement; 84% reduced premonitory urges; No tolerance development over years; Quality of life improved 76%

notes: Medical Cannabis for Tourette Syndrome: German Retrospective Study
abstract: 82% reported substantial tic reduction; 75% improved daily functioning; 68% reduced other psychiatric medications

notes: Cannabis for Tourette Syndrome: Online Survey of Patient Experiences
abstract: Tic improvement: 96%; OCD improvement: 76%; Anxiety: 72%; Self-injurious behavior: 68% reduced; Sleep: 84% improved

notes: Cannabinoid Therapy for Treatment-Resistant Tic Disorders: Multicenter Study
abstract: CGI response: 76% improved; Tics reduced 45%; Comorbidities (ADHD, OCD) also improved in 62%

notes: THC for Tourette Syndrome: First Randomized Controlled Trial
abstract: THC: Tic frequency reduced 35%; Tic severity reduced 41% (p<0.05); Global impression improved in 11/12 patients

notes: THC for Tourette Syndrome: 6-Week Treatment Trial
abstract: THC: YGTSS reduced by 35% vs Placebo: 8% (p<0.01); Significant sustained tic reduction over 6 weeks

participants: 97 adults with Tourette syndrome / chronic tic disorders
notes: Nabiximols for Tourette Syndrome: Phase II Trial (CANNA-TICS)
abstract: Nabiximols: TTS reduced 14.0 vs Placebo: 5.6 (p=0.003); Highly significant; Effect maintained at 13 weeks

notes: Dronabinol for Tourette Syndrome: US Pilot Trial
abstract: Dronabinol: YGTSS reduced 40% from baseline; 6/8 (75%) achieved clinically significant improvement

notes: Palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) Plus CBD for Tourette Syndrome
abstract: PEA+CBD: 28% tic reduction; Premonitory urges reduced; Non-psychoactive alternative showed promise

notes: Nabilone for Tourette Syndrome: Pilot Randomized Trial
abstract: Nabilone: 35% tic reduction vs Placebo: 12% (p<0.05); Proof of concept for FDA-approved cannabinoid

notes: Tetrahydrocannabinol and Cannabidiol in Tourette Syndrome
abstract: At week 6 vs baseline: YGTSS total tic score change -8.9 (±7.6) under active vs -2.5 (±8.5) under placebo; mixed-effects model showed greater tic improvement under active treatment (P=0.008)

notes: A Double-Blind, Randomized, Controlled Crossover Trial of Cannabis in Adults with Tourette Syndrome
abstract: No statistically significant product effect on MRVTRS; THC 10% (and to a lesser extent THC/CBD 9%/9%) improved secondary outcomes (premonitory urge/distress/global improvement) vs placebo

notes: A Pilot Randomized Placebo-Controlled Crossover Trial of Medicinal Cannabis in Adolescents with Tourette Syndrome
abstract: Feasible protocol with high visit/blood-test completion; CGI-I: 3 rated much improved on active vs 1 on placebo at 10 weeks; efficacy not powered

notes: Cannabinoids for Tourette Syndrome: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
abstract: Pooled SMD = -0.82 (95% CI: -1.21 to -0.43, p<0.001); Large effect size; Consistent benefit across studies

notes: Nabilone Add-On Therapy for Refractory Chronic Pelvic Pain
Non-Pharmacologic Self-Management of Dysmenorrhea Includes Cannabis
Cannabis as a Self-Management Strategy for Endometriosis Pain
Cannabis and Cannabinoids in Women's Health: A Scoping Review
Medicinal Cannabis Oil for Endometriosis-Associated Pelvic Pain
